title: A dealer gets the cost price of 15 oranges by selling 10 oranges. What is the percentage profit? - Quora

response.answer_text: Let's assume X is selling price of orange Selling price for 10 orange = cost price of 15 orange I.e. he gets 5 extra orange to make profit Hence profit = 5 × 'X' I.e. % profit = (profit / cost price ) * 100 =[ (5X)/(10X)]* 100 = [1/2] *100 = 50 % Percentage profit is 50% Let's assume an example like you bought 15 orange for 100 rs(cost price) and sell them at 150 rs (selling price) Then profit is 150–100 = 50 rs Percentage profit =( profit / cost price )*100 = (50/100)*100 = 50% Hope so this may help you 🙂

Statement of the given problem,A dealer gets the cost price of 15 oranges by selling 10 oranges. What is the percentage profit?Let C & S denote the cost-price & sell-price of an orange.Hence from above data we get as follows,10*S = 15*Cor S = (3/2)*C = (1 + 1/2)*Cor S = (1 + 50/100)*CTherefore it is evident from above thatthe percentage profit = 50% [Ans]
